column1: Primary amyloidosis is a disorder in which abnormal proteins build up in tissues and organs.
Symptoms depend on the organs affected.

Symptoms may include any of the following: - Abnormal heart rhythm - Swollen tongue - Fatigue - Numbness of hands or feet - Shortness of breath - Skin changes - Swallowing problems - Swelling in the arms and legs - Weak hand grip - Weight loss Other symptoms that may occur with this disease: - Decreased urine output - Diarrhea - Hoarseness or changing voice - Joint pain - Weakness
Body-wide (systemic) amyloidosis can lead to death within 2 years.
Call your health care provider if you have symptoms of this disease.
Also call if you have been diagnosed with this disease and have: - Decreased urine - Difficulty breathing - Swelling of the ankles or other body parts that does not go away
